job_title: Mother Baby RN in Houston, TX
pros: The nurses on my unit are truly like a mini family. We work really well as a team and someone will ALWAYS be there to help you when you're drowning in a rough assignment (which is most of the time). My coworkers and charge nurses are the main reason I'm still working at this job! Unfortunately, a good majority of the nurses on our unit are starting to seek alternative employment.
cons: This hospital feels more like a business than a hospital. The executives would rather a nurse take 7-8 high-acuity patients at a time and feel unsafe/on the verge of calling Safe Harbor than pay for the floor to be staffed appropriately so we could each have 4-6 patients and provide them with quality care. I am a competent nurse, yet I feel like my license is in danger every time I clock in for a shift because of the unsafe work environment and impossible expectations set for the nurses.

pros: Teamwork is second to none
cons: None I love the entire team

pros: There are no pros for working at this hospital.
cons:
I heard rumors about HCA in general but the opportunity to get into my dream field was what led me to taking a job here. 
A month after my job offer, the Friday before I started working on the following Monday, they tried making me sign a two-year $15,000 contract - for forcing me into a 16-week training that was "worth" that investment (interviewing manager said 8 weeks training).
I luckily declined and they dropped the contract, but not the program. After 4 weeks on the unit they pulled me to Cypress for this 16 week program, if we declined the program we were to be immediately terminated (although this program was not in our original job offer).
This company is unethical, dishonest, and has ZERO integrity. 
People you've never met (CNO, program directors, nursing director) will try to make assumptions about your character and you as a nurse - for bringing up concerns about their program and questioning the instructors.
In my short time there, the majority of the nursing staff was agency or contract as they could not keep hired employees. The manager was uninvolved and when asked about being forcibly pulled for the program she stated it "wasn't her domain and she wasn't getting involved".
In my 4-weeks on the unit, I had seen enough that gave me red flags: not scanning meds, putting in MD orders without ever speaking to the MD, not wasting narcotics, leaving epidural cartridges draining in sinks without supervision.

pros: The Staff Nurses are amazing!
cons: Overworked, under staffed, poor management, under paid

review_title: I will never work for this Hospital again.
pros: Pbx operator was easy, There are no other pros.
cons: Very Unorganized and unprofessional department and Hospital. None of the departments are on the same page.

pros: Flexible hours, self scheduling, good overall
cons: Pay and benefits could be more competitive

review_title: Losing good staff r/t undervaluing & under resourcing
pros: The employees, for the most part, value their patients and try their best to serve them. The doctors and nurses work at supporting each other, and although innovation is s-l-o-w here, the staff genuinely care about their work and do much good for many families.
cons: Although the staff value their patients this facility is hindered by its for profit values. While those who have direct care try hard, they have limited resources and often leave feeling deflated. Nurses aren't paid what they're worth (working a few blocks down the road most likely will earn you $10 more per hour). The pay isn't even the worst part, but just an example of the values of upper management. The staff is consistently asked to do more with fewer resources. For example, there is only one NICU educater and over 200 NICU nurses, not counting new hires & students.  They fired the previous educator because she had a master's degree & cost the company too much $ (and she had dedicated over 20 yrs to this place!). You get in trouble if you have to work late because of a busy assignment and yet there's no one in management who will look into the problem of being under resourced. 'It must be the nurses "milking" the clock. Um no, actually the staff are doing all they can to help their patients in spite of you.  Don't even get me started on the useless medical benefits.

pros: Great coworkers. Truthfully, that is what has kept me here so long. Free parking (although not well lit at night).
cons: Benefits could be better. Pay is a big issue when it's located down the street from the medical center. Staffing cuts ( not enough nurse techs, housekeeping, etc) play a large role in quality care (techs help nurses immensely, housekeeping to keep patient rooms clean--overflowing trash bins shouldn't be seen by visitors).

pros: Emerging opportunities I  Pediatrics growing  fast  with an excellent neonatal Care Unit  expanding with in the hospital . Well round team of staff members.
cons: Distance may be far for some to travel there. A period of  rapid expansion is requiring  a great deal of remodeling and the need for more personnel.

pros: Flexible schedule. Good work life balance.
cons: Always short staff. Leadership walks around talking and worrying about things such as rounding longs when nurses have 8-9 patients load. Leadership (managers, assistant managers) never assist with patient care even when very short staff. Short staff day here can mean a nurse taking 10 pts at one time.

review_title: Good experience, bad morale and no support from upper management.

cons: Upper management couldn't care less about employees. Everybody is replaceable  even though they spend thousands of dollars to train and orientate a NICU nurse.
